title: I live in Nevada and want to file bankruptcy. Do I have to file in Nevada or can I file in CA?
question: My second question is, does the attorney need to be licensed in Nevada as well? I'm currently in LA and it would be ideal with an attorney here can file the BK for me.
answers:
No, you must file in your district in your home state. The Attorney must be admitted in your local district.


Jonathan Leventhal, Esq..
Leventhal Law Group, P.C.
818-347-5800

-------- Original message --------

Just visiting won't qualify you to file bankruptcy in California. You will need to be living in California to file bankruptcy in California. The bankruptcy court staff in Nevada is very professional and if you must file in Las Vegas or Reno, will treat you with respect. Hope this perspective helps!

If you have lived in CA for 91 days before you file, then you file in CA. You would use a CA licensed attorney.

The issue is what exemptions do you use. You would not be eligible to use CA exemptions even though you are filing in CA. However, many state's exemptions can only be employed by residents. I don't recall if NV has such a provision, but I bet it doesn. In which case, you would default to federal exemptions.
Mr Chen is spot on with his answer.

Most bankruptcy cases can be filed in the jurisdiction where you have lived for the last three months. If you will have lived in LA for three months by the time you file your BK, you will not encounter venue objections.

If you do plan to file in CA, your attorney does not need to be licensed in NV. We practice in Los Angeles, so please contact us if you have any questions.
